Award.AwardTitle: RNA Polymerase-Specific Transcription Complex Assembly on snRNA Genes: Structural and Functional Relationships

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
ABSTRACT

Intellectual Merit: The small nuclear RNAs (snRNAs) known as U1, U2, U4, U5, and U6 comprise a highly abundant class of metabolically stable, non-polyadenylated RNA molecules that are required for pre-messenger RNA splicing in eukaryotic organisms. The spliceosomal snRNAs are synthesized by RNA polymerase II with the exception of U6, which is synthesized by RNA polymerase III. Despite this difference in RNA polymerase specificity, U6 genes and the RNA polymerase II-transcribed snRNA genes utilize similar cis-acting regulatory signals and overlapping sets of transcription factors for their expression. The main goal of the project is to gain an understanding of the structure-function relationships that are involved in polymerase-specific transcription complex assembly, with emphasis on the TATA-less U1 promoter, More generally, this project will help us understand how very subtle changes in macromolecular interactions and assembly can lead to significantly different biological outcomes.

Transcription of both classes of snRNA genes requires a unique multi-subunit transcription factor most commonly referred to as the snRNA-activating protein complex, or SNAPc. This factor recognizes an essential promoter element termed the PSE located within the region 40-75 base pairs upstream of the transcription start site. In the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster, SNAPc is composed of three subunits that together carry out sequence-specific recognition of the ~21 base-pair PSE (known more specifically as the PSEA in fruit flies). Even though a U1 PSEA and a U6 PSEA differ at only 5 of 21 nucleotide positions, this sequence difference plays a major role in determining the RNA polymerase specificity of insect snRNA genes. Furthermore, the three subunits of DmSNAPc adopt a different conformation when bound to a U1 vs. U6 PSEA. This conformational difference is believed to be responsible for the recruitment of the correct RNA polymerase.

To better understand the structural arrangement of the SNAPc subunits bound to a PSEA, a novel technique that combines site-specific protein-DNA photo-cross-linking with specific chemical proteolysis of the protein will be employed. These experiments will determine the orientation or polarity of each of the SNAPc subunits on the DNA. In flies, the TATA-binding protein (TBP) is used for U1 transcription by RNA polymerase II, but the TBP-related factor TRF1 is utilized for U6 transcription by RNA polymerase III. The domains of the individual SNAPc subunits involved in interactions with TBP or TRF1 will be identified. The fly U1 gene will serve as an excellent model for investigating transcription complex assembly on TATA-less RNA polymerase II promoters. Toward that end, the mechanism by which SNAPc recruits TBP to the TATA-less U1 promoter will be investigated.

Broader Impacts: The research will be performed by students working on their B.S., M.S., and Ph.D. degrees in biochemistry/molecular biology. The project will provide training for their future careers in the biotechnology industry, for advancement to graduate and professional schools, or to careers in academia. San Diego State University, due to its border location and emphasis on undergraduate as well as graduate instruction, serves a large body of undergraduate students from underrepresented ethnic groups. The principal investigator is active in undergraduate classroom teaching and has a strong track record and history of involving underrepresented students in NSF-funded research. The results of the project will be disseminated in peer-reviewed scientific journals and will contribute widely to the areas of transcription regulation and gene expression.

Intellectual Merit:

In higher organisms the correct expression of genetic information present in the DNA is crucial for the normal development of an embryo into an adult member of the species. In higher multi-cellular organisms, most genes are split into segments called "exons" that contain the coding information for a specific protein. The exons are separated from each other by "introns" that are not directly involved in coding for protein. During the process of "messenger RNA splicing", the introns are removed from the messenger RNA precursor in order to generate a functional messenger RNA that can code for the cognate protein product. The process of messenger RNA splicing requires the presence and activity of five essential small nuclear RNAs (snRNAs). In my research lab, we are studying the biosynthesis of these snRNAs that are absolutely required for the health and well-being of all higher organisms.

Our model organism for studying snRNA biosynthesis (or transcription) is the widely-used fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster. We chose this system because robust in vitro biochemical systems are not available for humans or other vertebrates to study the transcription of certain snRNA genes. Nonetheless, we expect that much that we learn in this model system will be translatable to the human system. All higher organisms possess three different RNA polymerases. Each synthesizes RNA from different sets of genes, and it is important that every gene be transcribed by the correct RNA polymerase. Interestingly, some of the snRNAs (for example, U1 snRNA) are transcribed by RNA polymerase II, but others (for example, U6 snRNA) are transcribed by RNA polymerase III. Our work is designed to uncover the molecular mechanisms that determine and specify which RNA polymerase is recruited to a particular snRNA gene.

A puzzling aspect of this question is that U1 and U6 snRNA genes have very similar regulatory sequences ("promoter sequences") in their DNA to which the same protein complex, the small nuclear RNA activating protein complex (SNAPc), binds. Although these promoter sequences are similar, they differ at certain important nucleotide positions that govern RNA polymerase specificity. We propose that these slight differences in DNA sequence affect the shape or conformation of SNAPc, and, as a result, different surfaces of SNAPc are exposed on U1 and U6 snRNA gene promoters that subsequently recruit the different RNA polymerases.

This NSF-funded project has allowed us to gain significant insight into the structure of SNAPc and how it interacts differently with U1 and U6 snRNA gene promoters. Drosophila SNAPc is composed of three separate protein subunits, and we mapped protein domains that are required for each subunit to assemble into the SNAP complex with the other subunits. We also determined regions in all subunits that are specifically required for SNAPc to bind to DNA. Finally, we have identified regions within the subunits that specifically contact DNA nucleotide positions within the promoter DNA sequence of U1 but not U6 genes, and vise versa. From these and additional follow-up studies, we are gaining significant information regarding a unique and unusual method utilized to regulate gene expression. This research will provide us with knowledge at the cellular and molecular level addressing how decisions can be made to select between two alternative biological pathways.

Broader Impact.

This project funded the education and training of four Ph.D. students, five M.S. students, and eight undergraduate students at San Diego State University.
